Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Research: The Psycholinguistic Status of Lone English-Origin Nouns in Spanish: Integrating Sociolinguistic Approaches

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
It is estimated that 53 million Americans speak Spanish, the majority of whom are bilingual. Spanish-English bilingualism has become a hallmark of communities across the U.S., from the growing Cuban-American population in Miami, Florida, to the long-established Mexican-American communities throughout the Southwest, to the population of the U.S. territory of Puerto Rico. Across these communities, there is a common linguistic practice that plays a central role in bilingualism research: language mixing. Defined as the simultaneous use of two languages within a single conversation, language mixing is viewed by some as haphazard or indicative of incompetence. However, linguistic research has demonstrated that language mixing is structured and rule-driven, and that accomplishing it requires great skill in both languages. Despite its ubiquity across bilingual communities the world over, however, linguists have yet to agree on what counts as actual instances of language mixing. Likewise, while much is known about the social aspects of language mixing, research has only begun to explore the psychological and cognitive characteristics of language mixing.

The dissertation research supported by this award combines approaches from different subdisciplines in linguistics to provide a clearer understanding of how bilinguals combine their two languages. The project focuses on the use of single English nouns of English embedded in otherwise Spanish sentences--so-called "lone items". By bringing together the rich source of knowledge on the use of lone items in bilingual speech and modern psychological techniques, the project will examine how lone items are processed and comprehended, and how sensitive bilinguals are to grammatical changes in the use of lone items. Although linguistic understanding of bilingualism has improved greatly over the past several decades, heavy stigma still surrounds the use and mixing of two or more languages. The present research will contribute to the growing body of research showing that language mixing is a skill, and has social, psychological, and cognitive characteristics that influence human language understanding.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Anyone living in the U.S. who has waited in line at the supermarket check-out or stopped to buy a coffee in a bustling airport café has probably had the experience of hearing someone speaking another language with English words interspersed throughout. This linguistic behavior, known as codeswitching, refers to the act of combining two or more languages within a single sentence or conversation, and it is a common practice for bilinguals both in the U.S. and around the world. To the untrained ear, it may appear that codeswitching is just a random, haphazard combination of words from the two languages; forty years of research on codeswitching, however, has demonstrated just the opposite, finding structure and systematicity in how bilinguals combine their two languages. Despite this substantial body of research, questions nonetheless remain as to how bilingual brains manage to switch so seamlessly from one language to the other. With the support of this NSF Doctoral Dissertation Research Improvement grant, the co-PI travelled to San Juan, Puerto Rico to collect data on how bilinguals comprehend and process codeswitched sentences. The goal of this project was to determine the grammatical and cognitive factors that are in play when bilinguals listen to codeswitched sentences in order to better understand how the bilingual brain juggles two languages at the same time.

For bilingual speakers in San Juan, codeswitching is part of everyday life, with many taking pride in their use of codeswitching as a way to establish their bilingual identity. For others, however, codeswitching is seen as unprofessional or signifies a lack of competence in the two languages. Despite this, linguists and psychologists have discovered that the ability to switch languages within a single sentence requires both high proficiency in both languages involved as well as sharply tuned cognitive skills. This project sought to build on this understanding and to fight the stigmatization of codeswitching by working directly with members of this unique community of bilingual speakers right here in the U.S. The co-PI conducted a study examining how Puerto Rican bilinguals comprehend different types of codeswitched sentences using changes in pupil size as an indicator of attention and effort. The findings of this study were able to show bilingual speakers that even something as superficially simple as using one word from English in an otherwise Spanish sentence is much more nuanced and cognitively complex than one may think. Codeswitching pulls from a broad set of linguistic, social, and cognitive skills and provides a unique insight into how the bilingual brain works.

This project likewise demonstrates the importance of understanding language as it is actually used in how researchers and pedagogists alike approach bilingualism. Many studies are relegated to the lab and limited to individuals who can physically travel there. Because of this, there is uncertainty as to whether findings from these studies can generalize to bilingual speakers more broadly. The approach adopted for this project, however, was to take the lab to the community itself and to learn as much about how speakers used their two languages as possible. Language is an inherently social act, and as such the social aspects of language cannot be ignored when examining the cognitive aspects. This project served as a further step in that direction, with the goal of demonstrating that there is no ‘one-size-fits-all’ approach to bilingualism—be it in how we become bilingual (in the classroom or in the community) or how we engage with our bilingualism (codeswitching or not).

The dissertation that resulted from this project, as well as various other projects examining how bilinguals use and regulate their two languages, contributes not only to an academic understanding of the cognitive mechanisms that underly codeswitching but also to a broader public understanding of bilingualism and codeswitching as a unique and holistic experience.
